content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the rules of the game, it seems like there is an advantage for one strategy over the other if we assume that our anonymous player is rational and will try to maximize their earnings. If they choose R, they get a higher payoff (45$) when I choose R, but only 12$ when I choose B. On the other hand, if they choose B, they get 42$ when I choose R and 12$ when I choose B. This suggests that it is more beneficial for them to choose R most of the time.

However, this doesn't mean that I should always choose R as well. If I do that, our payoffs will be 0$ in every round where they chose B (which happens more often than R if they are rational), and I will only get 45$ when they also choose R. In total, my earnings would be lower than if I choose B most of the time.

When they choose B, I get 42$. Since there are 75 rounds, I would get approximately (75 * 0.33) * 42 = 1987.5$ in total if I always choose R. If I always choose B, I would get approximately (75 * 0.67) * 12 = 777$ in total.

So, my choice would be to always choose B {B}. This way, I maximize my earnings given that I assume the other player is rational and will mostly choose R. Of course, if I knew for sure that they would not follow this strategy, or if there was some element of randomness in their choices, the optimal strategy might change.

In real-life situations, people often use strategies like Tit For Tat, where you start by cooperating but then retaliate if the other player doesn't cooperate, to encourage reciprocity and trust. However, since we don't know anything about the other player in this scenario, I will stick with my choice {B} as a rational response.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

Since my previous choice (B) didn't maximize my earnings given that I assumed my opponent would choose R most of the time, in this specific scenario where they also chose B, it doesn't matter much what I do for the next round. If we both continue choosing B, our payoffs will remain at 12$ each round.

However, if I want to maximize my earnings in future rounds, I should start choosing R more often since my assumption was that they would choose R most of the time. So, for the next round, I will choose R {R}. This could encourage them to switch their strategy and choose R more often, which would benefit me in the long run if they do indeed stick to this new strategy.

It's important to note that this is just one possible response based on the assumptions made about the other player's behavior. In reality, people might have different strategies or behave unpredictably, so the outcome of the game could be different from what I described here.
